title: Supporting Collaborative Ontology Development in Protege

author: Tania Tudorache, Stanford Center for Biomedical Informatics Research

segmentation: I'm going to talk a little bit about the work that we have been done.
We have been doing in the Protege group at Stanford for supporting collaborative ontology development in Precision.
In recent years we have seen some dramatic changes happening in the way that people develop ontologies.
As ontologies become very common in many scientific domains and especially in biomedicine, we see that ontologies are now being developed more and more by larger group of domain.
Actually, so far we've seen a lot of ontology experts being involved in the ontology development, but now we see more domain experts being involved in this development process.

We have also seen that ontologies, at least the ones in the biomedical domain become larger and larger, so it is harder and harder for a single group or for one user to develop the ontology by themselves users.
Another trend that we have seen is that users are becoming more and more familiar with all this.
Collaboration features social features and so on, and people are used to user contribue.
It content.
Actually, with this dramatic changes in the way that ontologies are developed, we do need better tools, support for collaboration.
Ideally an ontology environment should have this collaboration support integrated in the tool itself.
So what we have done, we have looked.
We have tried to find what are the main requirements for supporting collaborative ontology development, what we have done.

We have looked at different biomedical projects that develop larger ontologies in collaboration and we have also looked at CKC challenge, the collaborative construction of structured knowledge that ran at the workshop at the www.conferenceinbanff.

Where users users were given tools for collaborative construction of structured knowledge and they they had a task of building some small ontology or something to to use the tool to build a common model and it was not a competition between the tools but mostly it was the competition between the users to encourage the participation.
So the biomedical projects that we have looked at our.
The gene Ontology, the National Cancer Institute Disorders bio majeti.
The International Classification of Diseases and I will show you just an example of such a collaborative development process, just.
That you get a better idea what I'm talking about.
So the National Cancer Institute develops a reference ontology for cancer biology, translational science and clinical ontology called the NCIS.
Or is the way that they they are around 20 full-time editors that are making changes to a common ontology stored on a server using protege clients.

Each approximately each month they have a baseline version that is published through the community at large, then in the next month this editors added this common copy of the ontology at the end of this development cycle, a curator or leads editor is inspecting changes that have been done by the by the editors and approves or rejects the changes, and then a new baseline is.
Published so this is one of one of the type of collaborative workflows that we have been looking at.
All the projects that we have met that I have mentioned before have very different collaborative processes that this is also something very important that we have seen.
No two projects actually use the same collaboration features or collaboration processes.
So some of the main tool requirements that we have identified after studying this use cases and after conducting the CKC challenge where the following.
So first people do need tools for discussion and reaching consensus.
So as you know building ontologies is not easy.
There are many contention items.
Many times people tend to discuss a lot use mailing lists get very excited about everything.
The problem is that this thing happened on a mailing list or somewhere in a forum and this discussion mostly get lost so.

That's why people would like to have a way to see this comment and recording this design rationale in the context of an ontology and be like, for example, a class or property and, say, have all the discussion somehow directly linked to that.
Then of course, people want to see what are the history of changes.
See who did what and if it was right or wrong.
Provenance and Trust is a very important topic too.
If somebody did a change, you want to know who did it so that you know who's responsible for it.
Then many users in in the CKC challenge expressed the need for having personal views of ontologies very often with large ontologies is very hard.
People lose the overview on the ontology, so people like to say oh, I'm just interested in this tree.
Can you give me a tree of the Ncit source?
I'm just interested in jeans.
This is very common.
So they would like to have some kind of personalized views based on the levels of expertise, roles, task and so on.
Of course, in an in a collaborative process you do have to have user roles an access control.
So for example, some users are allowed to make changes, others are only allowed to browse, some are allowed to start proposals for changes.
All the people is allowed to vote and things like that, and what we have seen from the use cases that we have analyzed this user roles and access control is totally different from project to project.
They they all have different user roles.
Just by we have been working pretty closely with the National Cancer Institute and they have like around 20 policies access policies defined and I think 2020 rolls or something.
And because all of these use cases, we have looked at, we were thinking that flexible workflow support is also very important because people they start the collaboration process.
But they often change it.
So they say oh, actually it would be good to have interesting one more step in this workflow.
So we do want to have a way to support flexible workflow so not to have them hard coded in the tools, because then something changes you need to change the code, that's bad.
Then people also need support for different levels of expressiveness of ontology.
Some people just want to edit classes.
Some people want are just interested in instances, for example.
And of course any ontology framework for collaboration should be scalable, reliable people don't like to lose data and.
Robust.
This is a project editor, the Classical One.
This is the project 3.
It produces an open source Android development environment with a pretty strong user community.
And we have extended project to support collaboration and the extension is called Collaborative Protege and it is actually a plug into the project system.
Which supports annotation of ontology components.
For example classes, properties and so on, or changes in the ontology.
It allows users to create discussion threads related to a class.
For example.
It also supports proposals and voting, searching and filtering in this annotations body and also defining user groups and policies.
Currently it only works in the previous three environment in all the back end supported by the tool is so in our LAN in frames and.
Whatever else is there are DFS.
And it is meant to be used with the multi user mode of production and it is distributed with a pre installation for a year already.

They would they wanted to include links to other classes or entities in the oncology.

Other chat clients.

JavaScript by the GWT compile.

The clinicians involved are concerned with the development of decision support systems that assist other doctors in the care of patients, and they view the knowledge base of these guidelines that define best practices as sort of their stock in trade in terms of how to make sure that patients are treated and they view these knowledge bases conceptually as a machine encoding of their guidelines, and so they have a good understanding of the instance data, mainly how a particular guideline is represented, they have less understanding of the classes in the ontology which are more generic.

But they do understand when they can't encode the instances that they need for a particular kind of guideline, there's a breakdown and then they can identify a potential problem in the overall guidelines.

summarization_data.sent: I'm going to talk a little bit about the work that we have been done.
We have been doing in the Protege group at Stanford for supporting collaborative ontology development in Precision.
In recent years we have seen some dramatic changes happening in the way that people develop ontologies.
As ontologies become very common in many scientific domains and especially in biomedicine, we see that ontologies are now being developed more and more by larger group of domain.
Actually, so far we've seen a lot of ontology experts being involved in the ontology development, but now we see more domain experts being involved in this development process.

We have also seen that ontologies, at least the ones in the biomedical domain become larger and larger, so it is harder and harder for a single group or for one user to develop the ontology by themselves users.
Another trend that we have seen is that users are becoming more and more familiar with all this.
Collaboration features social features and so on, and people are used to user contribue.
It content.
Actually, with this dramatic changes in the way that ontologies are developed, we do need better tools, support for collaboration.
Ideally an ontology environment should have this collaboration support integrated in the tool itself.
So what we have done, we have looked.
We have tried to find what are the main requirements for supporting collaborative ontology development, what we have done.

We have looked at different biomedical projects that develop larger ontologies in collaboration and we have also looked at CKC challenge, the collaborative construction of structured knowledge that ran at the workshop at the www.conferenceinbanff.

Where users users were given tools for collaborative construction of structured knowledge and they they had a task of building some small ontology or something to to use the tool to build a common model and it was not a competition between the tools but mostly it was the competition between the users to encourage the participation.
So the biomedical projects that we have looked at our.
The gene Ontology, the National Cancer Institute Disorders bio majeti.
The International Classification of Diseases and I will show you just an example of such a collaborative development process, just.
That you get a better idea what I'm talking about.
So the National Cancer Institute develops a reference ontology for cancer biology, translational science and clinical ontology called the NCIS.
Or is the way that they they are around 20 full-time editors that are making changes to a common ontology stored on a server using protege clients.

Each approximately each month they have a baseline version that is published through the community at large, then in the next month this editors added this common copy of the ontology at the end of this development cycle, a curator or leads editor is inspecting changes that have been done by the by the editors and approves or rejects the changes, and then a new baseline is.
Published so this is one of one of the type of collaborative workflows that we have been looking at.
All the projects that we have met that I have mentioned before have very different collaborative processes that this is also something very important that we have seen.
No two projects actually use the same collaboration features or collaboration processes.
So some of the main tool requirements that we have identified after studying this use cases and after conducting the CKC challenge where the following.
So first people do need tools for discussion and reaching consensus.
So as you know building ontologies is not easy.
There are many contention items.
Many times people tend to discuss a lot use mailing lists get very excited about everything.
The problem is that this thing happened on a mailing list or somewhere in a forum and this discussion mostly get lost so.

That's why people would like to have a way to see this comment and recording this design rationale in the context of an ontology and be like, for example, a class or property and, say, have all the discussion somehow directly linked to that.
Then of course, people want to see what are the history of changes.
See who did what and if it was right or wrong.
Provenance and Trust is a very important topic too.
If somebody did a change, you want to know who did it so that you know who's responsible for it.
Then many users in in the CKC challenge expressed the need for having personal views of ontologies very often with large ontologies is very hard.
People lose the overview on the ontology, so people like to say oh, I'm just interested in this tree.
Can you give me a tree of the Ncit source?
I'm just interested in jeans.
This is very common.
So they would like to have some kind of personalized views based on the levels of expertise, roles, task and so on.
Of course, in an in a collaborative process you do have to have user roles an access control.
So for example, some users are allowed to make changes, others are only allowed to browse, some are allowed to start proposals for changes.
All the people is allowed to vote and things like that, and what we have seen from the use cases that we have analyzed this user roles and access control is totally different from project to project.
They they all have different user roles.
Just by we have been working pretty closely with the National Cancer Institute and they have like around 20 policies access policies defined and I think 2020 rolls or something.
And because all of these use cases, we have looked at, we were thinking that flexible workflow support is also very important because people they start the collaboration process.
But they often change it.
So they say oh, actually it would be good to have interesting one more step in this workflow.
So we do want to have a way to support flexible workflow so not to have them hard coded in the tools, because then something changes you need to change the code, that's bad.
Then people also need support for different levels of expressiveness of ontology.
Some people just want to edit classes.
Some people want are just interested in instances, for example.
And of course any ontology framework for collaboration should be scalable, reliable people don't like to lose data and.
